Rodin’s project for the Museum of Living Artists at the Seminary of Saint Sulpice, however, indicates some influence of the Cambodian Royal Ballet on his subsequent work. In 1907, Rodin was commissioned to create fresco for the Museum, intended to house part of the collections of the Musée du Luxembourg. The decorative scheme was to be based on Paradise, a foil for the display of Gates of Hell. René Chéruy, Rodin’s secretary in 1907, wrote that Rodin dreamed of using the Cambodian dancers in his frescoes. While the project was discarded in 1913, plans indicate that the Cambodian dancers, linked in Rodin with antiquity, participated in his vision of Paradise.
